title: When did the idea of teaching students 'how' to think not 'what' to think appear? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s a great question - and we should not assume that education in all of human history has been ‘what to think’ - the Greek philosophers had schools… and some education didn’t include thinking at all - it was rote recitation. In modern history - in the US - I think discussions of thinking and fostering thought - might be found in the writings of John Dewey - the late 19th/early 20th century psychologist/philosopher and he might have been influenced by the Kindergarten movement in Germany which wasn’t just about adding a grade to school - but as a reform movement of sorts - the 1960s was the decade of revisionist scholarship - and how to think not what to think has certainly been under discussion since then- Metacognition - we should look up when that word was introduced to K-12 educators as a worthy approach to teaching and learning - it would inform the search for the origin(s) of ‘how to think’ -
with pythagoras? but, there’s the insidious ‘how to think about…’, when used to close off the mind to speculation. so, ‘how to think about god’?, asked by a priest or an ‘atheist’.
